pr_title: [RW-3790][RW-3587][Risk=low] Remove named params and move to bigrquery

timeline.bodyText: Is this going to handle strings vs numbers properly? Wouldn't strings need to be quoted?
timeline.author: calbach

replies.bodyText: I think the key is always @key_name, so this should work?
replies.author: s-rubenstein

replies.bodyText: Sorry, I should have highlighted the code block. I meant to refer to the value with this comment, not the key, i.e. line 704
replies.author: calbach

replies.bodyText: I will take a look at that.
replies.author: s-rubenstein

replies.bodyText: What was the outcome here?
replies.author: calbach

timeline.bodyText: Did you look at str_glue as Nicole suggested? I think it would be more readable to declare variables then substitute them into the templated SQL as is done in the snippets. Note: it would require setting up an additional package
timeline.author: calbach

replies.bodyText:
+1 . I get scared seeing system calls in the middle of a complex string operation. We need to have the cleanest, earliest error code we can if one of those values is missing or malformed.
Also, I'll give you a dollar for every string or regex replacement we can kill in this class. 😉 I believe we can build almost everything up in one direction, and that's much easier to reason about and test. Later PR of course.
replies.author: jaycarlton

replies.bodyText:
Where is the str_glue comment? I didn't see that in the email I got.
I do hate the amount of string replacement we're doing, but we would need to go into the cohort builder sql builder to change it too much. (Unfortunately we're using the same SQL building code that they use.)
replies.author: s-rubenstein

replies.bodyText: Sorry I'm not sure if she explicitly suggested this, I was more thinking you were basing the approach on the code she had already written for the snippets menu. Here's an example of str_glue: https://github.com/all-of-us/workbench-snippets/blob/f6e714328ba8c0d3ff11387944fccb0df5ba7ab5/sql-snippets/snippets_setup.R#L30 ; see more complicated variants by inserting from the snippets SQL menu. The relevant thing here is that it lets you interpolate variables into a string.
replies.author: calbach

timeline.bodyText:
I don't love inlining these into the SQL itself. I think string substitution within the notebook code would be more reusable / understandable / readable. In R: str_glue, in Py f""
Alternatively, the parameterized queries in Python were perhaps an ideal way to show how to properly use BigQuery, but understood that diverging this much between R and Python could be a problem.
timeline.author: calbach

replies.bodyText:
I am happy using str_glue or f"", but honestly, I'm unsure what benefit it gives over the config or query parameters (They're both variables that get substitutions in)
I can revert back to that if we like. BigRQuery does just have it use a parameter option instead of a configuration option, so it does trim a lot of boilerplate and just make it basically a substitution.
replies.author: s-rubenstein

replies.bodyText: The benefit is that it can work with arrays in R, otherwise I'd prefer config/query parameters.
replies.author: calbach

timeline.bodyText: This deserves a comment, it seems like you're trying to replace the {project}.{dataset} templates within the query parameters at this step. But I'm not very clear on why
timeline.author: calbach
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -324,7 +324,14 @@ private DataSetRequest generateDataSetRequestFromPreviewRequest(
     DataSetPreviewResponse previewQueryResponse = new DataSetPreviewResponse();
     DataSetRequest dataSetRequest = generateDataSetRequestFromPreviewRequest(dataSetPreviewRequest);
     Map<String, QueryJobConfiguration> bigQueryJobConfig =
-        dataSetService.generateQueryJobConfigurationsByDomainName(dataSetRequest);
+        dataSetService.generateQueryJobConfigurationsByDomainName(dataSetRequest).entrySet()
+            .stream()
+            .collect(
+                Collectors.toMap(
+                    Map.Entry::getKey,
+                    stringQueryJobConfigurationEntry ->
+                        bigQueryService.filterBigQueryConfig(

replies.bodyText: nit: just use e for entry in an inline lambda. The extra-descriptive name is great for a class method or function name, but for single-arg lambdas I tend to expect the other extreme.
replies.author: jaycarlton

replies.bodyText: I tried checking this and it appears to be nonsense, so I removed it
replies.author: s-rubenstein

timeline.bodyText: There should probably be at least one test which incorporates parameters
timeline.author: calbach

revised_code.chunk:
diff --git a/api/src/test/java/org/pmiops/workbench/api/DataSetControllerTest.java b/api/src/test/java/org/pmiops/workbench/api/DataSetControllerTest.java
index 09656dd74..e6b84bd8b 100644
--- a/api/src/test/java/org/pmiops/workbench/api/DataSetControllerTest.java
+++ b/api/src/test/java/org/pmiops/workbench/api/DataSetControllerTest.java

@@ -692,7 +703,7 @@ public class DataSetControllerTest {
     String prefix = "dataset_00000000_condition_";
     assertThat(response.getCode())
         .isEqualTo(
-            "import pandas\nimport os\n\n"
+            "import pandas\n\n"
                 + "# The ‘max_number_of_rows’ parameter limits the number of rows in the query so that the result set can fit in memory.\n"
                 + "# If you increase the limit and run into responsiveness issues, please request a VM size upgrade.\n"
                 + "max_number_of_rows = '1000000'\n\n"

timeline.bodyText: nit: maybe name this like domainToBigQueryConfig.
timeline.author: jaycarlton

timeline.bodyText: nit, naming: This was confusing to read. I don't see where "project information" comes in. I suspect there's a better name.
timeline.author: jaycarlton

timeline.bodyText: nit: I feel like just having the builder inline would be more readable than calling this helper, since you're really only assigning the legacy Sql. You could also have a function that returns a builder with the default arg set, like return QueryJobConfiguration.newBuilder().setUseLegacySql(false);. That's if it lets you make a builder without the query. 🤷‍♂
timeline.author: jaycarlton

replies.bodyText: I can do the function that returns a builder with the arg set, that seems reasonable to me. Because its in two places, I would prefer having the default args change in both with one change.
replies.author: s-rubenstein

replies.bodyText:
Talked offline:
I tried to address the comment here https://github.com/all-of-us/workbench/pull/3103/files#diff-5324f051d4e486d6f33e30b9f6bebd92R500 but it looks like all the builder methods that don't require a query up front are private methods. 😢
I could have it build each time it is used, but that ends up with a bunch of repeated boilerplate for the defaults.
11:20
(I could maybe build with an empty string literal and then set the query later?) (edited)
11:20
Do you have a preference?
Jay Carlton  11:26 AM
it's not a huge win to do what I think I was saying
11:26
just pointing out that builders smaller than ~5 lines are all right inline unless there's lots of repeated fields
replies.author: s-rubenstein

timeline.bodyText: nit: it would be more robust to have a list of things to import,  roll over it to make import statements, and then join that with a newline.
timeline.author: jaycarlton

timeline.bodyText: nit: I generally don't want to see three languages in one function.Can we wrap the bodies of these case clauses into their own functions?
timeline.author: jaycarlton

replies.bodyText: Sure, will do.
replies.author: s-rubenstein

timeline.bodyText: Too much is happening here to test effectively or to really understand. Please do put comments at the top of this function and split up the string operations.
timeline.author: jaycarlton

replies.bodyText: Will do.
replies.author: s-rubenstein

timeline.bodyText: I'd make a helper function like  formatArrayValueStringValuesOrWhatever(QueryParameterValue queryParameterValue) that gives you everything you're concatenating here.
timeline.author: jaycarlton

timeline.bodyText:
nit: I think this reads better with Optional.ofNullable(...).ifPresent(v -> stringBuilder.replace(..., v)
But also, I'm not used to seeing replace used on a stringBuilder. It's generally expected that you build up the correct string from the beginning. Is there a way to do the swapping earlier?
timeline.author: jaycarlton

replies.bodyText: Not without changing the Cohort Builder SQL building code, unfortunately. Will change to the Optional.ofNullable method though.
replies.author: s-rubenstein

replies.bodyText: OK, I really want to get to tinkering on a new third party query builder.
replies.author: jaycarlton

timeline.bodyText: We need to have test cases for all the edge cases,  like when things that are expected to be there are missing. We should be failing the operation early instead of sending a broken query to the notebook if anything is amiss. (We don't have a great automatic way to find all the notebooks with queries for a given release yet from what I remember.)
timeline.author: jaycarlton

timeline.bodyText: Do we need to upgrade our notebook docker image to include bigrquery?
timeline.author: jmthibault79

replies.bodyText: I think the ticket said we don't have to in this case... Don't quote me on that.
replies.author: jaycarlton

replies.bodyText: It functions without it, so we should be good. My guess is Leo includes it by default?
replies.author: s-rubenstein

replies.bodyText: Great.  I'll add it to my sanity-checking notebook.
replies.author: jmthibault79

timeline.message: Remove named params and move to bigrquery
PR feedback without str_glue or additional tests
PR feedback without str_glue or additional tests

timeline.bodyText: If I'm reading this correctly, this turns into: WHERE ICD9 IN (2, 5). This doesn't seem right
timeline.author: calbach
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -716,27 +728,16 @@ public void testGetPythonQuery() {
                 + "condition_source_concept_id IN (123)) \n"
                 + "AND (c_occurrence.PERSON_ID IN (SELECT * FROM person_id from `"
                 + TEST_CDR_TABLE
-                + ".person` person)) "
+                + ".person` person WHERE "
+                + NAMED_PARAMETER_VALUE.getValue()

replies.bodyText: In this case, I just threw some random text in. In truth, it is more likely to be something like WHERE concept_id IN (132543, 2135643...)
replies.author: s-rubenstein

replies.bodyText: Could you change it to be a more realistic value? I think future editors will find this confusing
replies.author: calbach

timeline.message: Fix linting and add integer64 typing
